pros: Big machine, leading in research, employs a lot of people in the area. Too big to fail.

The people who are left at the place --- and they are cutting many MANY jobs --- either ate their young to survive or are very good at hiding and taking a beating. They blew through an enormous budget with nothing to show and now layoffs are every other day. Managers have lists of expendable people -- no longer people but positions and numbers. They culled the young to keep their big titles and laugh with pompous candor at the meanderings of the minions. It's the most awful experience that required therapy while working there and after working there. Most people in marketing are not actually from the area the hospital serves. They look down upon the people here like bugs under a psychotic kid's burning magnifying glass. The psychological damage is real. Would never recommend to a friend. An enemy, likely.

review_title: Depends on what YOU want out a job or career
job_title: Non Licensed Dispensing Optician in Danville, PA
pros: Very decent health benefits (though every year the options change as does the increase you pay for your benefits). You now accrue PTO faster, also Paid Parental Leave option (implemented in the last 4 years).
cons: Started out as a great company/healthcare system with great intentions, but has gone downhill over many years with the changing of the guard (top executives over the years). Too much tooting of the old horn/look-at-me this is how I'm helping people - when you get down the to the nitty gritty it's not helping people the way it was intended, just more for show and bragging rights. Good competent management and good coworkers is luck of the draw depending on what department you land in. Billing system currently a mess. A HOT mess. Expanding company quickly, but not utilizing already existing (and empty) buildings, instead opting to build more offices that may not be able to be adequately staffed. Implementing tech options that are supposed to "help" and be "user friendly" options (self check-in kiosks with facial recognition), but are neither for people who are "older" and did not grow up with computers and or of stricter Anabaptist backgrounds - both demographics we deal with. For now there are PARR's to help check them in, but remains to be seen if there will be people to help, or if self check in will become the norm.

review_title: Solid employment, but lots of silos and little advancement
pros: On the up side, Geisinger is a solid employer. Once you get in, if you are good at your job, you will have a job indefinitely (taking into account any major market changes). People were generally nice and they really care about patients and serving the community. Benefits were competitive. Also, for tech folks, very good work from home policy (at the time, and that was pre-COVID).
cons: Teams tend to be stagnant. Doing a job well can work against you because you won't see much advancement. Promotions are hard won because they don't like to move staff around too much. Unless you self-advocate somewhat aggressively, you can find yourself working in the same dept, under the same manager, for quite a long time. Even if that manager is good, this can be bad for your future carrier because you don't get further experience and opportunity.

review_title: Geisinger Wyoming Valley? More Like Hell on Earth.
pros: There are absolutely no pros to working here.
cons: Working here, especially within the lab department, is probably the worst decision you'll ever make. The pay is absolute TRASH. You're working in a hospital, putting yourself at risk every single day, and you're doing it for a whopping $15.25/hr. Not to mention, the hours are ALSO trash. If you want to work somewhere that offers a work/life balance, this isn't the place for you, either. Your mornings WILL start at 4-5AM, you'll have rotating weekends and holidays, and good luck getting a day off. They make YOU find someone to cover your shift, and if you can't find anyone willing, you're basically sh*t out of luck. They're constantly hiring for day shift because the turnover rate is insane. There is ZERO professionalism, management is a joke, the entire department is petty, and there is absolutely NO "teamwork" here. A majority of the other Phlebs. will avoid entering certain patient rooms, and actually HIDE from the floor they're supposed to be on to purposely avoid having to do their jobs. If you are any type of person that sticks up for themselves, you won't make it here. It's all about seniority, rather than respect, and all of the "supervisors" are legitimately useless. They will legitimately harass you and make your life hell, expect you to bend over and take it, and the second you stand up for yourself, they'll fire you for having a "negative attitude". This place is a nightmare, and I can't believe I ever worked there in the first place, let alone for such a pitiful excuse for an hourly wage. If you're a Phlebotomist, work in a Plasma Center. The clientele is nicer, the hours are better, and the pay is a lot higher. Avoid this place completely.

job_title: IT Service Desk Analyst in Wilkes Barre, PA
pros: You receive a pay check.
cons: The job is very stressful and demanding, but it is due to the organizations unwillingness to hire competent employees. The day to day is not to fix technical issues, but more to fix issues of other departments mistakes/being an emotional punching bag. For example, the organization had one of the worst transitions from working in office to at home. As a result, the load of unpreparedness was met with the IT Service Desk and we were only given a simple thank you and "limp hand shake" for the grueling hours it took to transition 30,000 employees to work from home. In addition, there was an influx of calls, for patient services, and their need to access their MyGeisinger(MyChart). The organization was once again unprepared for another drastic situation and patient care was hugely affected for days/weeks, but it was another task for the IT Service Desk to face as usual. Lastly, I would like to state that the incompetency's of the medical/office staff and their inability/lack of wanting to educate themselves on IT equipment/programs. It is mind boggling the amount of ignorance that these employees spew out of their mouths and how much they will refrain from trying to resolve their simple issues. For example, it is known task to have to reset passwords every Monday, because the staff will forget them over a simple 2 - 3 day weekend. It is also the most difficult to retrieve a tag numbers for a computer, because that task is "not their job..". Overall, there are many more examples that can be provided to shine light on this poorly created hospital, but I for one do not want to be a part of its mistakes any longer. I encourage you to look else where for IT employment and to refrain from assisting such a poorly managed company.

review_title: The good, the bad and the ugly
pros: good pay compared to smaller hospitals around. Good working with employees. Fun to to work with. Very knowledgeable doctors from prominent medical, dental and other medical backgrounds
cons: Where do i start. First, manegment thinks they know what is best. They think they know everything there is to know about a certain field. Some of the administrators don't have a bacchelors degree. Most have an associates or some form of high school. They told me that I can't work extra hours but I can fill in on a shift. I do not get OT. I can only work a certain amount of hours and they yell at me when I make more than usual. They want the staff to work at its maximum x25, but have the minimalist amount of aid from other empoyees and attention of administrators. They want to cut corners by thinking they have more education than a doctor. The hosital is tp heavy. 600-650 doctors and about 300-450 nurses. The reest of the 3,000-5,000 employees are hospital administrators who do not generate income. Those are some of the main points. There are thousands of reasons. Coworkers were extremely loud and disruptive and made fun of disabled patients who were going to dialysis appointments across the street. There were also lots of racist remarks. They constantly and loudly talked trash on everyone else. It was very distracting. 

The one coworker was so hostile acting everyone was afraid to do anything about it. The manager condoned their behavior and even joined in. 

That group was allowed to be on their phones all day but anyone else got in trouble for it. It was double standards and cattiness all around. It made the job unbearable. 

The manager for that area was immature and clearly not qualified enough to hold that position. Adults were acting like teenagers. That kind of behavior is unacceptable to the work place and is an embarrassment to all of Geisinger.

review_title: Great institution. However, removed from urban amenities and poor pay.
pros:
- Fully integrated multispecialty medical group with mature EMR (EPIC). 
- Collaborating and communicating with colleagues is very easy.
- Ability to provide gold standard of care to patients.
- Capable and friendly colleagues. 
- Generous PTO and CME allowance.
- Benefits from day 1.
- Good retirement plan.
- Ample opportunities for participating in committees, quality improvement projects, research and teaching. 
- Medical management is mostly receptive to ideas related to improving things around.
- No traffic.
- Patients are mostly respectful to healthcare workers in comparison to most cities.
cons:
- Low salary for some physicians (they were unable to afford to pay me the 10th percentile for my specialty)
- Minimal raises. 
- Space is a premium for some departments. I did not have an office.
- Removed from urban amenities (3 hours away from a real city)
- Mediocre public schools with the exception of Lewisburg school district. No good private school alternatives.
- Long commuting for outreach clinics for some specialties (20-90 miles)

review_title: Excellent first job, yet little opportunity for career advancement
pros: The Geisinger Center for Health Research (CHR) is a state-of-the-art research building that provides a great atmosphere and confortable workspace. The coworkers are friendly and highly team-oriented with high morale. The benefit package is generous and employees have access to plenty of healthcare resources. Employees also have a fair amount of say in the job functions that they perform.
cons: the education requirements and job description do not accurately line up with the actual job functions and pay. Therefore, all too often do overqualified employees take positions in the CHR only to leave shortly afterwards for better career opportunities (and pay). Upward mobility is severely hindered as seasoned employees are often overlooked for promotions in favor of overqualified new-hires. This has caused an environment of very high turnover rates (under a year for positions such as research assistant and project coordinator), with employees often leaving shortly after they are trained to adequate performance. While this is commonplace in many industries, it has perhaps more of an impact on such a research institution where projects which span several years rely on consistency.

review_title: Don’t even bother! Geisinger ruined what was left of Holy Spirit Hospital!

cons: For a company that has this big-time personality test before hiring, they seem to be turning away good candidates and pulling in some lazy & rude employees. There’s a lot of bullying, backstabbing, and racism in this hospital and the practices. There’s nastiness towards patients. Management says they can’t do anything about it. Understaffing,  The pay scale is way off. Employees are unappreciated and disrespected.  There’s no focus on patient care. It’s become a very selfish company that states its main focus is morals and values but yet it’s full of liars and hypocrites.

review_title: There's a reason I left, and a reason I came back
pros:
For the Company:
- Large medical facility, providing excellent patient care in a rural setting
- Excellent time off plan, if you're full-time
- Excellent benefits from day one, if you're full-time
- Excellent health insurancem if you're full-time
- Room to grow professionally
- Collaborative atmosphere
- Interested in providing excellent patient care
- Gives back to the community
- Selectively taking on other clinics and hospitals in the area, to prevent their dissolution, and to maintain quality care for the region
- Physicians work for the hospital, not at/from it.
- Geisinger was an early adopter of EMR (EPIC), and put a lot of effort into building and maintaining its IT

For my department:
- No micro-managing
- Friendly coworkers and team-mates
- Ability to work independently
- Management has my back in most cases
- Management is very understanding of time off needs and work/life balance
- Management is approachable
- Team building stuff, such as fitness challenges, picnics, etc.
cons:
For the company:
- Hard to get hired. I started through the in house temp, and when a position was specifically created for me to go full-time, HR's applicant tracking system said I was unqualified.
- If you're not full-time, you're not going to get much of anything
- Doctor's often have god complexes and ridiculous egos
- Nursing staff feels overworked and under-appreciated
- A general sense of being too large
- A disjoint between upper management and everyone else, despite management's efforts

For IT:
- IT is goo large, and too departmentally fractured to work effectively. 
- Collaboration is in name only

For my department:
- IT as a whole is so large that it often feels like teams are working against each other
- A sense of distrust / blaming / etc between teams
- Undercurrent of favoritism

pros: Geisinger takes their commitment to employees seriously. The health benefits are outstanding, provided through the insurance arm of the organization. The company promotes growth from within and continuing education, including tuition reimbursement. Overall, the employees are kind and care deeply for the patients, clients, members and their community.
cons: Some departments have incredibly high turnover, especially in the support areas, and many of the locations Geisinger has properties, including the headquarters, are in small towns. Although bigger cities are within a 2.5 or 3 hour drive, it's still some distance away. Some may have a difficult time adjusting to small town life, and many employees within the organization were born, raised or moved back to the area of employment.

review_title: They hire for character and credentials but technology is from the 80’s.
pros: Open to new ideas and why I chose to write a review. Pay including benefits, caring staff, and flexible work schedule.
cons: Technological software is extremely slow and not intuitive. They claim to be innovative but the servers can’t keep up with the growth. Computers including PC’s and laptops are older than a decade.

pros: I worked in a small department at Holy Spirit and loved my job. My supervisor and the director were encouraging, respectful, and always available. I looked forward to getting up every day and going into work. The health benefits (which included dental and vision) were great and tuition reimbersment was a plus.
cons: The pay for my position wasn't great, but I was afraid to negotiate when I was hired and was excited to have a decent job in my field of study.

pros: Fast paced, excellent working conditions.  Lots of learning opportunities for employees who seek them out.  Access to world-class healthcare.  Non-smoking environment.  Emphasis on employee health; cafeteria has good healthy-eating choices and most locations have a place where employees can work out.  Employer contributes to 401k (vested after 3 years).  Can have prescriptions delivered directly to office.
cons: The usual office politics, same as anywhere.  Successful employees focus on their work and don't get involved.  Employee parking is bad.  Some managers reject viable solutions because they don't understand the new technology.

review_title: Company that Cares - Top Company in Central PA
job_title: Human Resources Coordinator in Danville, PA
pros: Great benefits, pay, and opportunities for advancement.  Those are the reasons I wanted to come to Geisinger.  They still apply but I stay because of the great supportive team I work with, and because as a company Geisingers strives to be innovative and focus on doing the right thing.  Geisinger is not resistant to positive change, and when something “we’ve always done” is in question it is accepted as opportunity to improve.
cons: The onboarding process was more difficult than expected but worth it in the end.

review_title: Good Career choice- depending on what department you land in
pros: Progressive health system-leader in health care, innovative. Truly focused on hiring bright, talented Physicians and Specialists.
cons: certain departments have high turnover, in part due to the cliques that are prominent. Watched many new college grads arrive with high hopes of fitting in and starting a promising career, only to be knocked down by leadership cliques. Especially true if you are an above average looking young woman. The other women, supposed leaders, can be brutal. Not all departments, worked in several that were just bad-.

pros: Mission of college is admirable.
cons: Ability to accomplish tasks is hindered by lack of management, insufficient accountability and oversight.

pros: An organization-wide focus on using data from research and experience to provide the best possible patient care.  Great support for people who want to grow in their field.  Opportunities in all aspects of healthcare, with motivated colleagues from around the world.
cons: There is intensifying pressure to find ways to do more with less resources, both from a culture of continuous improvement and from a marketplace heavily influenced by one consumer that is less able to pay for requested services each year.

cons: Unsafe working conditions, poor quality of some personnel, negative attitudes, mismanagement. Anti-gay sentiment, and sexist attitudes. You must cover yourself because when sometime goes wrong, fingers WILL be pointed.

pros: I couldn't ask for a better place to work! I love the people I work with and serving our community. Most people in leadership roles seem to genuinely care about their employees.
cons: I disagree with the administration taking away snack and drink choices they deemed unhealthy. Every person should have the right to make their own choice.

pros: Extremely supportive co-workers and management. Very organized orientation and training program. Great benefits. OK pay. Lots of freedom to prioritize tasks and increasing workload as you got more skilled at your job. Always made the lower members of the team feel like their contributions were invaluable.
cons: Workload and independence depends on your project manager. Luckily mine was amazing and really allowed me to contribute to the study but I saw many coworkers being micromanaged by other PMs.

job_title: Service Desk Analyst in Danville, PA
pros:
Geisinger invests highly on technology and has one of the largest pool of Tech support teams. With over 30 thousand employees we have a multitude of hardware and software to support.  Working for a First Tier support is not for the weak. In the beginning you will be exposed to the fire hose of thousands of documentation that you may need to troubleshoot technical issues, along with having the ability to speak to a user to walk them through. You are not expected to memorize and know all of this knowledge but know where to find the information to help a user through.
You really don't get a sense of things, until you have been here for at least 6 months and you really don't catch on to the flow until about a year. There are many people that are willing to help you along, and they do give you every chance to do well.  Currently there have been restructuring to improve IT. 
When working in this environment you are working with many personalities and levels of ability. There are many great managers that do make this type of job better. We all work together in a team environment to give the best customer service.  You will feel overwhelmed at first but you will do well.
Something you may help to know when working at this level. 
Be understanding that everyone has different personalities so be patient with your co-workers. We all come here with many talents, be willing to share what you know to make the overall experience to customers better. Don't expect you will know everything in a short amount of time, technology always changes, so give this some time.
Geisinger has a position for your specific Technical Talent, if after a year you feel you can use your talent in another department you have that opportunity to take another position as an internal candidate.
It is a plus to have great customer service skill, and if you were thinking on getting your certifications in any of the tech fields like A+, Network+ etc then do it.

I personally love working here. I have great managers (I have worked other places where the management was not the best) I love talking to the users and trying to put a smile on their face, I love learning something new everyday. My co-workers are great people and I appreciate their own individuality.  The benefits are great, and they keep improving upon them.
cons: Communication across departments, clashing of personalities, drama, tendency for clique environment

pros: There is a lot of turnover in the company leaving room to advance and build your resume. Years ago I could see myself working here and nowhere else and would often speak fondly of the company.
cons:
The company is pushing a culture of kindness and trying to highlight the things they do for staff like fixing equipment for example which they should be doing anyways. 
At the end of the day though while you look at the shiny new thing they are doing to engage you working in a short staffed department. They are telling your manager to meet a productivity number and justify any replacement position, you have to many people, or your department has positions open and your co-workers are burning out, calling off or just getting a different job because the only applicants getting through are those “aligned” from a survey the applicants get and must complete in order to work a front line position. All while the company itself reported increased profits over prior years that was released in a local newspaper from the media department.
I could get similar pay, hrs, and benefits without the added work being dumped on us from positions not being replaced by working at a hotel, restaurant, or senior center.

review_title: Overall, my experience has been a pleasant one.
pros:

2) Geisinger has, in the past,  cared deeply for their employees and their opinions
3) Good leadership at Geisinger
cons:
1) Starting to get away from that sense of family that once was there
2) Starting to be unbalanced, as far as who does what - no clear expectations

job_title: EHR Systems Analyst in Bloomsburg, PA

Head of Epic is the biggest con. Due to her actions, I saw a lot of great, talented people leave Epic, or the wrong people promoted. Several people actually received promotions when they threatened to leave. Fix that problem, and perhaps, overall moral for Epic teams across the board will improve. 
Also, it's part of the job, but 24/7 on call can make for tiring work day.

pros: Culture shift in last two years moving to more layers contributing ideas and identifying problems. Long term employees in abundance; teamwork is not just a word but an expectation and it makes everyone's job better.
cons: Still executive layers heavy, culturally older Caucasian men rule. Some salary ranges don't make sense. Still working to recover from direct patient care workforce reduction from 3 years ago .

pros: Nice benefits, great paid time off. Ability to work remotely. OT available sometimes. Good training program. New CEO with vision.

It is totally unbelievable. One employee is late everyday and takes long breaks and nothing is ever said only excuses. Maybe we all should work that way since it is allowed.

I am currently in school for my Masters and could not have done it without Geisinger's tuition reimbursement.
cons: Everyone has bad moments, but we don't allow them to turn into bad days!

review_title: Work harder but with less resources
pros: Good salary, cheap cost of living, the employees are terrific, good retirement plan
cons:
Managers fear the higher ups, they do not support their employees. This year everyone was informed there would be a 5% cut in expenses and there would be a hiring freeze. The company also wanted a 3% increase in productivity. In response, I asked for more clinic time to see more patients but I was told there was not enough support staff to allow this to happen. How then can I increase productivity?

Because of the anticipated drop in revenues, physician compensation will decrease this year. Everyone was told their base salary and bonus would be increased 1-2% but Geisinger imposed new metrics you had to attain to get your bonus. These metrics are difficult to achieve. Despite the 1-2% promised increase, my total compensation will be 3% less than last year.

Complaints are not tolerated. 
We are told to accept and not question any leadership edict. If you do not agree, you can leave. No one feels special as they are all considered replaceable. The fact there is a continuous revolving door with more health staff leaving should trigger concern among their recruiters and subsequent leadership concern, but this fear is dismissed.

cons: geisinger health insurance has a 500 deductible, forces you to use mail order for prescriptions, company discriminates against smokers, will not employee smokers. HR representatives are not availabe and do not respond to your questions.  HR department makes decision about punishments/suspensions or warnings without speaking to you at all.  CPSL schedulers have very difficult jobs because office staff refuse to answer telephone calls  to assist patients with symptoms, med issue or other problems. The patients have extremely high hold times and are angry when they get to the schedulers, putting a lot of pressure on the scheduler to have a decent call.  I have had numerous callers with serious symptoms and could not get nurses to answer the phone. The nurses would pick up the phone and hang up on us.  We told management about this issue but nothing was ever done about it.  There is no communication within the organization itself.  I took an entry level job in the hopes to branch out to a better job but I did not make it that far.
